Nit Warning: Quartzite is not harder than quartz. They both have a hardness of 7 on the Mohs scale. 

For more detail, quartz is a mineral, and it defines hardness of 7 on the scale. Quartzite is, in modern geology, metamorphosed quartz sandstone, so a metamorphic rock. Quartz sandstone is sandstone made up almost exclusively of quartz grains, plus quartz cement in varying degrees, so a sedimentary rock. (Quartz sandstone is called quartzite sometimes, but that's not currently cool, and only muddies the waters.)

If you take quartz sandstone and squash the heck out of it, you wind up with quartzite. Squashing it, though, doesn't change the hardness of the quartz that both rocks are made of. Squashing gets rid of the holes and recrystallizes some or all of the quartz grains, but it's still quartz, and the hardness of that is 7.

Countertop manufacturers are known to exaggerate. 

In case anyone wants a better example for 28A: like graphite vis-√†-vis diamond. Both are carbon, but wow are they different hardnesses!

Late comment. Couldn't help but wonder about an alternate clue for HUE. Well... multiple times in the pre-Shortz era but only twice in the Shortz era (out of 114 appearances). What am I talking about? Well - here's a true story from one morning in Vietnam. 

We had arrived by chopper on a firebase late one evening. The next morning after we got up, one of the guys looked out to the east and said, "Oh! You can see the ocean out there." And... one of the other guys said, "Really? Can you see Hue out there?" 

And he replied, "Oh yeah - way, way out there."

That was a good puzzle, but I do have to quibble about the notion that quartzite is HARDER than quartz. First of all, quartzite (a rock) is made up of fused quartz (a mineral) grains. It's the same stuff. Second, hardness is a mineral property defined as resistance to scratching. You can't apply to a rock, although you can apply it to separate mineral grains in a rock (in which case, see my first point). Third, you might argue correctly that quartzite is more resistant to breakage than quartz, because the fused, interlocked grains stand up better to crushing. But that property is not called HARDNESS; it's  TOUGHNESS.  So, [Like quartzite vis-√†-vis quartz] is a misleading clue for HARDER.

A more interesting pair are diamond and jade. Diamond resists scratching much better than jade (so it's HARDER), but it fractures much more easily than jade (which is extremely TOUGH).

@Francis
Lawyers.

I am very familiar with the species. They share (I am sorry to say) with surgeons the delusion that humans are like tinker toys and if I can just twist this one piece over here back into place, everything else will fall back into place and all will be well.

But humans are very complex and the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. I recently read about the idea that "More is Different." That every time you introduce something into a complex system, everything realigns. So you need to look at everything and not just assume that, if you didn't change it, it will remain unchanged. I suppose that this is to avoid another basic problem -- the Law of Unintended Consequences.

So my advice (not that you asked) is to flip a coin. If it's heads, do today's puzzle. If it's tails, do the Sudoku or make some homemade bread or get a haircut. Call an old friend who lives far away and say, "Howyadoin, kiddo?" Stare at the snow through the window for 15 minutes. (No cheating, use a timer.) Or, if you must have words, read a book. Try Thomas Mann; he seems to be in the air now.

Because it's just a game.
PS You don't always have to obey the coin either. You are free.

@Abe Dillon
Graphite is a naturally occurring mineral, like quartz. Both are what we call native minerals, which means you can find each mineral lying around, not just in rocks with other minerals. It's made of sheets of carbon, bonded (covalent?) in a honeycomb pattern, which are stacked and bonded by weak van der Waals bonds. 

I had to look up graphene, interesting stuff. Graphene is a single layer of graphite. It's the isolation of these layers that makes them useful, and Nobel-prize worthy. The physicists isolated the graphene using graphite and adhesive tape! I remember reading about that.

So to address your question, yes, graphite is a mineral, and graphite is made of layers of graphene. So I guess graphene is a structure, not a mineral in the geologic sense. We can't really give it a hardness, cuz it's only one atom thick, and hardness is a physical property measured by scratching one thing against another. Geologists start backing away when you get to the molecular level.

@Barry Ancona
I gather they are. You can call meatloaf a steak if you want, but that doesn't mean I am going to pay $50 for it in a restaurant. 

I looked up both materials. It's a sea of conflicting claims. Quartz countertops are quartz (hardness 7) mixed with other stuff, like resins (hardness <7). Not sure what quartzite is, the photos show all kinds of countertops that are clearly not the rock quartzite. This is true for "granite" countertops, too. Saying a countertop has a hardness of 7-8, when the hardness is 7 at best, is marketing. Garnet is the only mineral that I can think of that is both harder than quartz and reasonably present in a giant slab of rock. Garnet isn't rare, like topaz and sapphire, but it's not going to be a dominant mineral in a countertop. When it comes to countertops, apparently you can claim just about anything, which does make them useful for a crossword puzzle. 

And I'd like to draw your attention to the first two words of my original post: nit warning. For me, there is tension between crossword puzzles, with giant gray areas, and science, which is the constant search for definitive answers. The tension makes it fun, but also occasionally leads to "well, shoot, that's not true."
